sen.j: 鋳掛屋（いかけや）とは、鋳掛を行う職人を指す。
sen.e: Ikakeya indicates the craftsman who does the work of ikake (repairing pots and rice cookers).
Ikakeya indicates the craftsman who does the work of ikake (repairing pots and rice cookers).
Ikakeya indicates the craftsman who does the work of ikake (repairing pots and rice cookers).

sen.j: 鋳造された鍋、釜などの鋳物製品の修理を行う職業。
sen.e: It is a craftsman that repairs the casting pots and rice cookers.
It is a craftsman that repairs the casting pots, rice cookers and so on.
sen.cmt: and so onを足しました。
sen.e: It is a craftsman that repairs the casting pots, rice cookers and so on.

sen.j: 鋳かけ、または鋳鐵師との表記もされる。
sen.e: It is also described as '鋳かけ' or '鋳鐵師.'
It is also written as Ikake or Ikakeshi.
sen.cmt: ローマ字表記にしました。
sen.e: It is also written as Ikake or Ikakeshi.

sen.j: 江戸時代から昭和期にかけての家財道具である鍋、釜は鋳造によって作られていた。
sen.e: The pots and rice cookers, which were household goods from Edo to Showa Period, were made with casting.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The pots and rice cookers which were household goods from Edo to Showa Period were made by casting.
The pots and rice cookers which were household goods from Edo to Showa Period were made by casting.

sen.j: だが、当時の鋳造技術ではスが入りやすく、またひび割れ等により穴が開くことがあった。
sen.e: But with the low level of casting technology in those days, pots and the cookers easily got hollow inside them, and sometimes got a hole by cracking.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: But it made a hollow inside easily with the low level of casting techniques in those days, and sometimes got a hole by cracking.
sen.cmt: technology→techniqueBut～文の前半部分を修正しました。
sen.e: But it made a hollow inside easily with the low level of casting techniques in those days, and sometimes got a hole by cracking.

sen.j: その一方、「月夜に釜を抜かれる」といったことわざにみられるように、鍋釜は泥棒が真っ先に狙うほどの大変な貴重品であった。
sen.e: Meanwhile, pots and rice cookers were the valuable goods that thieves tried to steal first and foremost, as a proverb 'rice cooker was stolen on a moonlit night (being very careless)' indicates.
Meanwhile, pots and rice cookers were the valuable goods that thieves tried to steal first and foremost, as a proverb 'rice cooker was stolen on a moonlit night (being very careless)' goes.
Meanwhile, pots and rice cookers were the valuable goods that thieves tried to steal first and foremost, as a proverb 'rice cooker was stolen on a moonlit night (being very careless)' goes.

sen.j: 従って穴が開いたとしても容易に捨てたり買い換えたりするわけにいかず、修理しながら使っていたのである。
sen.e: Therefore, as people in those days could not afford to easily throw it away or replace it even if it got a hole, they had to continue to use it by having it repaired.
Therefore, as people in those days could not afford to easily throw it away or replace it even if it got a hole, they repaired it over and over to continue to use it.
sen.cmt: 最後の部分を少し修正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, as people in those days could not afford to easily throw it away or replace it even if it got a hole, they repaired it over and over to continue to use it.

sen.j: その修理業者が鋳掛屋である。
sen.e: And the repairer that did the repair work was ikakeya.
And the repairer who did the repair work was ikakeya.
And the repairer who did the repair work was ikakeya.

sen.j: "銅鐵の鍋釜の破損を修補す、ふいごを携え来たりて即時に之為す。
sen.e: "Ikakeya repairs the holes or cracks of iron or copper pots and rice cookers, and he carries his bellows and repairs them immediately.
"Ikakeya repairs the holes or cracks of iron or copper pots and rice cookers, and he carries his bellows and repairs them immediately.
"Ikakeya repairs the holes or cracks of iron or copper pots and rice cookers, and he carries his bellows and repairs them immediately.

sen.j: 其の扮(見た目)三都(江戸・京都・大阪)相似たり"
sen.e: The act of ikakeya doing the repair work is similar in the three biggest cities (Edo, Kyoto, Osaka) in Japan.
The act of ikakeya doing the repair work is similar to the three biggest cities (Edo, Kyoto and Osaka) in Japan.
sen.cmt: similar in→similar to, Kyoto and Osaka
sen.e: The act of ikakeya doing the repair work is similar to the three biggest cities (Edo, Kyoto and Osaka) in Japan.

sen.j: 町中や村々を呼び巡り、声をかけられたら仕事をした。
sen.e: Ikakeya walked around towns and villages crying out, and when he was asked, he started the job.
Ikakeya walked around towns and villages calling out, and when he was asked, he started the job.
Ikakeya walked around towns and villages calling out, and when he was asked, he started the job.

sen.j: 右図の鋳掛屋は、道具箱にちゃんとふいごを持参している。
sen.e: The right figure shows that an ikakeya carries his bellows properly.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The right figure shows that an ikakeya carries his bellows properly in his tool box.
sen.cmt: 訳抜け。 in his tool boxを補足しました。
sen.e: The right figure shows that an ikakeya carries his bellows properly in his tool box.

sen.j: 融点の低い鋳鉄で鋳造された当時の鍋・釜を直すために鋳鉄片を溶融しうるだけの熱量は、これぐらいの装備でも確保できていたのだろう。
sen.e: It can be imagined that the enough heat amount to repair the pots and rice cookers casted with a low melting point in those days could be obtained by such simple equipment.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It can be imagined that the enough heat amount to melt a piece of cast iron for repairing the pots and rice cookers casted by cast iron with a low melting point in those days could be obtained by such a simple equipment.
sen.cmt: 訳抜け。 by cast iron を補足。また、「鋳鉄片を溶融しうるだけの」の部分が抜けていたので補足しました。
sen.e: It can be imagined that the enough heat amount to melt a piece of cast iron for repairing the pots and rice cookers casted by cast iron with a low melting point in those days could be obtained by such a simple equipment.

sen.j: 語源は金属を「鋳て」（溶かして）「かける」から「いかけや」である。
sen.e: The origin of the word ikakeya comes from '鋳て (ite)', which means to melt the metal and 'かける (kakeru), which means pour.
The origin of the word ikakeya comes from the combination of 'ite' which means to melt the metal and 'kakeru' which means to pour.
sen.cmt: 日本語表記を除きました。 means pour→means to pour, the combination of を補足しました。
sen.e: The origin of the word ikakeya comes from the combination of 'ite' which means to melt the metal and 'kakeru' which means to pour.

sen.j: 明治、大正時代までは鍋・釜の品質が向上しなかったので鋳掛屋商売も成り立っていた。
sen.e: As the quality of pots and rice cookers had not improved until Meiji and Taisho era, ikakeya were able to continue their trade.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As the quality of pots and rice cookers had not improved until Meiji and Taisho period, ikakeya were able to manage their business.
sen.cmt: continue～の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: As the quality of pots and rice cookers had not improved until Meiji and Taisho period, ikakeya were able to manage their business.

sen.j: だが、昭和期に入ると急速に廃れてゆくことになる。
sen.e: But the business began to fade out rapidly in Showa Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: But the business began to fade out rapidly in Showa Period.
But the business began to fade out rapidly in Showa Period.

sen.j: ただし、鋳掛の技術そのものは現在でも必要とされている。
sen.e: However, the technique of ikake itself is still needed even today.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the technique of ikake itself is still needed even today.
However, the technique of ikake itself is still needed even today.

sen.j: 小型の鐘、大釜などを片手間に鋳掛ける鋳造業者もある。
sen.e: There are some casters that repair temple bells and large rice cookers on the side.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There are some casters that repair temple bells and large rice cookers in their spare time.
sen.cmt: on the side→ in their spare timeに修正しました。
sen.e: There are some casters that repair temple bells and large rice cookers in their spare time.

sen.j: 川柳 "鍋鋳掛け すてっぺんから煙草にし" 仕事を始めた鋳掛屋がいきなり煙草で一服するのをおかしがる内容。
sen.e: There is a senryu (satirical haiku) "Nabeikake Suteppenkara Tabakonishi," which humorously depicts the ikakeya who has just started his work suddenly begins to smoke.
There is a senryu (satirical haiku) "Nabeikake Suteppenkara Tabakonishi," which humorously depicts the ikakeya who started his work with taking a whiff suddenly.
sen.cmt: Ikakeya who～の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: There is a senryu (satirical haiku) "Nabeikake Suteppenkara Tabakonishi," which humorously depicts the ikakeya who started his work with taking a whiff suddenly.

sen.j: 炉の温度が上がるまでは手持ちぶさたのため。
sen.e: This is because he had nothing to do until the temperature in the furnace rose.
This is because he had nothing to do until the temperature in the furnace rose.
This is because he had nothing to do until the temperature in the furnace rose.

sen.j: すてっぺんとは「最初から」の意味。
sen.e: suteppen' means 'from the beginning.'
Suteppen means 'from the beginning.'
